ABSOLUTE CINEMA

there i saw a comment

item.title: Dhurandhar, 2025 - ★★★★
item.description:
I'm not changing the rating but, on second watch i can truly realise how short of a time ranveer's character was given, it's really absurd how it is his movie and his character is given crumbs to work with.
if his backstory was shown, it would somewhat make his case wayyy better.
let to rest the flaws, the movie is action packed and a very engaging watch, you do not get bored at all, but in getting the engagement it lost to some parts in the script where it was just a plethora of very impactful dialogues delivered half hazardly.
this is something I'd rate 3/5 if I saw it on OTT first, but because of the huge theatrical advantage it has rn it's a 4/5.
item.dc:creator: Ashmit Avash

item.title: Stranger Things 5: The Finale, 2025 - ★★★½ (contains spoilers)
item.description:
This review may contain spoilers.

first movie of the year, and probably one of the most anticipated endings to a show.

i grew up with this show, i watched s1 and was way too scared of the demos of s2, eventually i gave in and watched that too.

don't get me wrong but this ending was a tad bit empty for me. it did give closure to the series as needed but lacked in dialogue, deliver and script pretty bad.

it was carried hard by the stunning performances by Gaten Matarazzo and Joey Keery, alongside with David Harbour, Sadie Sink and Nell Fisher. They were the only ones who I believe gave remarkable perfomances in this extravaganza.

It was filled with dispersed tension and quite a few plot holes with the biggest one being "If Jim Hopper is dead, how does he get to be the chief of police, didn't he fake his death to hide?", it's either i'm too dumb to find the answer or it's just never answered.

would I say it was a great ending? no
would I say it was a good ending to a show that I grew up with for like 10 years of my life? absolutely
item.dc:creator: Ashmit Avash

item.title: Frankenstein, 2025 - ★★★★★
item.description:
a very honest and heartfelt adaptation from the original source material,
it tackles the question of life and death with the proper nuance needed
and it all comes full circle when it ends with where it all started,
a man who envisioned and achieved the extraordinary being fascinated by his own vision, sitting an awe of realisation of the inhumanity of his own human dream

"Rest now, Father. Perhaps now, we can both be human."
item.dc:creator: Ashmit Avash

item.title: Dhurandhar, 2025 - ★★★★
item.description:
i was skeptical of the runtime because it is LONG but how well it is paced might be one of the greatest things pulled off.
such a big successful movie, but i have not many complaints from it, that is rare esp in hindi cinema.
the gore too wasn't overdone, it was tasteful, as much as it is required and not a tad bit more.
i really wanted the gaalis to be uncensored welp here we are cockblocked by india's cbfc, nonetheless it was such a great movie.
tbh it was more of a "akshaye khanna the movie ft. ranveer singh" but i guess the worldbuilding required one movie time to establish this huge world.
solid movie fr and a fully theatrical experience.
item.dc:creator: Ashmit Avash

item.title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower, 2012 - ★★★★★
item.letterboxd:filmTitle: The Perks of Being a Wallflower
item.description: i do not think the pain i felt will be gone any time soon, AND I WILL WATCH IT AGAIN.
item.dc:creator: Ashmit Avash

item.title: Homebound, 2025 - ★★★★
item.description:
one of the best movies i've probably watched come out of 2025, i really wanted to watch it in theatres but they had minimal screenings at odd hours which is extremely unfair to a movie like this.
it is perfectly deserving of being india's pick at the oscars, it breaks us apart with every moment, shown the pain of how difficult it is to be discriminated on the basis of caste and religion.
here is the reality, the ground reality, for those who still don't understand it maybe this movie is a reminder to let them know, and make them care.
item.dc:creator: Ashmit Avash

item.description:
i have reasonable doubt that if someone watches this movie they would not find it intriguing.
it is just so immersive, and the fact that it doesn't really change locations is the cherry on top.
12 people, 12 different perspectives and all felt so real.

item.title: The Perfect Neighbor, 2025 - ★★★½
item.description:
this is absolutely devastating.
you know that something is gonna happen, heck, it's truecrime you KNOW what's gonna happen but still it's so devastating to see.
and the bodycam footage is so genius, it perfectly portrays the entire story without even a single more word to be spoken.
harrowing, yet, realistic storytelling.
item.dc:creator: Ashmit Avash

item.title: Beautiful Boy, 2018 - ★★★★½
item.description:
this movie gives you a shit ton of hope, and you feel skeptical about it. it slowly eases you in to that hope and the *SNAP* takes it all away in an instant.
it desperately wants you to know that you are not alone, and you are warned against the power of addiction time and time again.
it does not explore how the person goes through it, much rather it explores how the people around the person go through the horror of watching their love one be addicted to substances, living life on the edge and never knowing when they'll see their loved one alive again.
item.dc:creator: Ashmit Avash
